title: Efficient Pauli channel estimation with logarithmic quantum memory
abstract:
Abstract
Here we revisit one of the prototypical tasks for characterizing the structure of noise in quantum devices: estimating every eigenvalue of an n𝑛n-qubit Pauli noise channel to error ε𝜀\varepsilon. Prior work [14] proved no-go theorems for this task in the practical regime where one has a limited amount of quantum memory, e.g. any protocol with ≤0.99​nabsent0.99𝑛\leq 0.99n ancilla qubits of quantum memory must make exponentially many measurements, provided it is non-concatenating. Such protocols can only interact with the channel by repeatedly preparing a state, passing it through the channel, and measuring immediately afterward.
This left open a natural question: does the lower bound hold even for general protocols, i.e. ones which chain together many queries to the channel, interleaved with arbitrary data-processing channels, before measuring? Surprisingly, in this work we show the opposite: there is a protocol that can estimate the eigenvalues of a Pauli channel to error ε𝜀\varepsilon using only O​(log⁡n/ε2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝜀2O(\log n/\varepsilon^{2}) ancilla qubits and O~​(n2/ε2)~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\tilde{O}(n^{2}/\varepsilon^{2}) measurements. In contrast, we show that any protocol with zero ancilla – even a concatenating one– must make Ω​(2n/ε2)Ωsuperscript2𝑛superscript𝜀2\Omega(2^{n}/\varepsilon^{2}) measurements, which is tight.
Our results imply, to our knowledge, the first quantum learning task where logarithmically many qubits of quantum memory suffice for an exponential statistical advantage.
